Instrument_Host.name: Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory A
Instrument_Host.description:
The Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory (GRAIL) spacecraft consists of two nearly identical spacecraft, GRAIL-A and GRAIL-B, designed using technology from previous missions, including the Lockheed Martin Experimental Small Satellite-11. Each spacecraft carries a science payload that includes the Lunar Gravity Ranging System (LGRS) for measuring distance changes between the two orbiters and a MoonKAM for public outreach.
GRAIL operates in four mission configurations: launch, cruise, lunar orbit insertion, and science operations. It includes a Command and Data Handling system, propulsion subsystems, and attitude control mechanisms, all designed for optimal functionality during operations around the Moon. The DSN supports GRAIL's communication needs by providing two-way contact between the spacecraft and Earth through its three global complexes, equipped with various antenna sizes for effective data transmission and monitoring.
Overall, the GRAIL mission utilizes a combination of onboard instruments and DSN assets to conduct thorough radio science investigations into lunar gravity and other scientific inquiries.
